results.title: Wind
results.brief_description: A child’s first discovery of wind - the silent, invisible something that tickles his fancy, ruffles his hair, ripples the grass around him - is portrayed here in winsome animated drawings, utilising sound but no verbal communication.
results.description: A child’s first discovery of wind - the silent, invisible something that tickles his fancy, ruffles his hair, ripples the grass around him - is portrayed here in winsome animated drawings, utilising sound but no verbal communication.

results.title: Wind
results.brief_description: Shows kite-flying, sailboats, pinwheels and swaying branches to illustrate the power of the wind and introduce the words wind, tree, sea, blow, boat, spin, fly and kite.

results.title: Winchester
results.brief_description: Describes Winchester, one of the great historical cities of England. Shows the 13th century West Gate; Winchester College founded in 1382; Wolvesey Palace (now a ruin) dating back to 1138; Winchester Cathedral (started in 1079, completed in 1486). It was also Winchester where King Alfred held court and Jane Austen lived.

results.title: Win, lose or draw
results.creator_credit: Heather Williams, Graeme MacLeod, Australia. Special Broadcasting Service and Excalibur Nominees
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Australian mosaic”.
The staging of the Americas Cup in Fremantle had a huge impact on the redevelopment of Perth’s old seaport. Heritage buildings were restored, some lovingly, some superficially and new tourist and shopping precincts were created. This program explores the short and long-term effects of the development on the people of Fremantle, both rich and poor, businessmen and tenants and should give valuable lessons to others planning major redevelopment around a once-off major event such as the Americas Cup.

results.title: Wills and inheritance
results.brief_description: Produced in response to the heavy demand for information on this subject, “Wills and inheritance” examines various aspects of the legal process involved in making wills. Often misunderstood, this important subject effects us all. In documentary style, experts in the field explain topics such as “Why make a will?”, “Contesting and changing wills”, “What happens if you don’t make a will?’, “How to make a valid will”, “The processes of probate”, and “Cultural considerations.”

results.title: Willoughby's magic hat
results.brief_description: An animated recreation of the historic events that occured to Samson’s hair after it was cut by Delilah. This comic film claims that Delilah knitted a cap out of Samson’s hair and gave it to her other boyfriend Hercules. Since then, the cap has journeyed through history bestowing strength and courage on new owners. This century, the cap was purchased by a meek and mild character called Willoughby who used the cap’s magical powers to fight crime and evil on the street’s of his city. We see Willoughby bravely saving a damsel in distress, climaxing with her rescue from the path of oncoming trains.

results.title: Willingly to school (TEFC)
results.brief_description: This film looks at some of the changes that British schools are making towards emphasising not the ability to memorise facts but the quality of thought itself. It shows the educational implications of Professor Jean Piaget’s work - especially the need to gear teaching to the child’s learning processes.

results.title: William Shakespeare, background for his works
results.brief_description: Shows the places of Shakespeare’s times and the elements of his English life that gave the poet-playwright his language and shaped his character. Kenilworth Castle, Stratford, the River Avon, the Anne Hathaway cottage and a model of the original Globe Theatre are portrayed. Brief episodes are presented from some of the plays of Shakespeare: “Romeo and Juliet”, “Macbeth”, “Taming of the Shrew”, “The Merchant of Venice”, and “Hamlet”.
